message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: State-of-the-Art and Future Research Challenges in UAV Swarms
Paper Abstract: Due to their potential to accomplish complicated missions more effectively, UAV swarms have attracted a lot of attention lately. UAV swarm offers enhanced intelligence, improved coordination, increased flexibility, survivability, and reconfigurability. It is a multi-disciplinary system that necessitates a tight integration of several sub-systems, including optimal trajectory planning, localization, task coordination, etc. This review covers the important aspects of UAV swarms including swarm formation control, communication, swarm path planning, autonomy, coordination, and security. It additionally explores recent technical advancements in UAV swarm algorithms that have made the development of complex UAV swarm systems possible. This paper also provides insight into ethical aspects and the use cases of UAV swarms in various military, civilian, and entertainment applications. This paper is concluded by highlighting the potential future directions and challenges of UAV swarm technology and the need for more research and development to exploit their potential fully. Overall, this paper presents a comprehensive review of UAV swarm technology, addressing its potential for revolutionizing many fields and supporting advancements in the future.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've performed a web search for "Formation control" and here are the results:

The search returned several different contexts for this term:

1. **Robotics and Control Systems**: Formation control refers to the control of robotic systems, which is an area of research in evolutionary and biomorphic robotics. More broadly, control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems, with the aim to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state.

2. **Oil and Gas Industry**: In oil well control, the technical aspect involves preventing the formation gas or fluid (hydrocarbons), usually referred to as kick, from entering into the wellbore during drilling or well interventions.

3. **Political Context**: In government and political science, there are also concepts related to formation, such as a formateur, which is a politician appointed to lead the formation of a coalition government after either a general election or the collapse of a previous government.

The most relevant result for "formation control" in an engineering context appears to be its application in robotics, referring to coordinating the movements and positions of multiple robotic systems to maintain a desired geometric formation.

Links: [{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"File:Motion planning workspace 1 configuration space 2.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Motion_planning_workspace_1_configuration_space_2.svg"},{"title":"File:Motion planning workspace 1 configuration space 1.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Motion_planning_workspace_1_configuration_space_1.svg"},{"title":"File:Motion planning workspace 1.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Motion_planning_workspace_1.svg"},{"title":"File:Motion planning configuration space road map path.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Motion_planning_configuration_space_road_map_path.svg"},{"title":"Kinodynamic planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinodynamic_planning"},{"title":"OMPL - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OMPL"},{"title":"Category:Automated planning and scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Automated_planning_and_scheduling"},{"title":"Topological complexity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_complexity"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of motion planning:

## Definition

Motion planning, also known as path planning or the navigation problem, is a computational problem to find a sequence of valid configurations that moves the object from source to destination.

## Applications

Motion planning has several robotics applications, such as autonomy, automation, and robot design in CAD software, as well as applications in other fields, such as animating digital characters, video games, architectural design, robotic surgery, and the study of biological molecules.

## Basic Problem

A basic motion planning problem is to compute a continuous path that connects a start configuration and a goal configuration, while avoiding collision with known obstacles.

## Algorithms

Low-dimensional problems can be solved with grid-based algorithms that overlay a grid on top of configuration space, or geometric algorithms that compute the shape and connectivity of free space.(no content)Sampling-based algorithms are currently considered state-of-the-art for motion planning in high-dimensional spaces, and have been applied to problems which have dozens or even hundreds of dimensions.

## Related Concepts

Real-time path planning consists of motion planning methods that can adapt to real time changes in the environment. Additionally, kinodynamic planning is a class of problems for which velocity, acceleration, and force/torque bounds must be satisfied, together with kinematic constraints such as avoiding obstacles.

Web search results for query: "Autonomy artificial intelligence"

Links: [{"title":"Political Declaration on Responsible Military Use of Artificial Intelligence and Autonomy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_Declaration_on_Responsible_Military_Use_of_Artificial_Intelligence_and_Autonomy"},{"title":"Autonomous agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agent"},{"title":"Collaborative intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence arms race - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_arms_race"},{"title":"Artificial consciousness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_consciousness"},{"title":"Artificial general intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence"},{"title":"Open letter on artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_letter_on_artificial_intelligence_(2015)"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Self-driving car - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-driving_car"},{"title":"Lethal autonomous weapon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lethal_autonomous_weapon"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about autonomy in artificial intelligence:

## Key Concepts

An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently.(no content)In artificial intelligence, an intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.

## Types of Autonomous AI Systems

In the context of generative artificial intelligence, AI agents are a class of intelligent agents distinguished by their ability to operate autonomously in complex environments.(no content)Agentic AI expands this concept by proactively pursuing goals, making decisions, and taking actions over extended periods.

## Levels of Autonomy

When discussing artificial general intelligence (AGI), researchers define five levels of autonomy: tool (fully in human control), consultant, collaborator, expert, and agent (fully autonomous).

## Real-World Applications

Autonomous AI is being applied in various domains:
- **Autonomous vehicles:** Artificial intelligence plays a pivotal role in the development and operation of autonomous vehicles, enabling them to perceive their surroundings, make decisions, and navigate safely without human intervention.
- **Military systems:** There are ongoing discussions about lethal autonomous weapons systems, with concerns about how autonomy should be defined and regulated.

## Challenges and Concerns

Autonomous agents must make decisions with limited or uncertain information about their environment and future states. Incorporating autonomous agents into existing systems and workflows can be technically challenging and resource-intensive.

Web search results for query: "Swarm robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Swarm robotic platforms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotic_platforms"},{"title":"Swarm robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics"},{"title":"Ant robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant_robotics"},{"title":"Swarm (novelette) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_(novelette)"},{"title":"Swarm intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_intelligence"},{"title":"Kilobot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kilobot"},{"title":"S-bot mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S-bot_mobile_robot"},{"title":"Sabine Hauert - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sabine_Hauert"},{"title":"Gerardo Beni - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerardo_Beni"},{"title":"IISc Guidance, Control and Decision Systems Laboratory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_Robotics_Laboratory_at_IISc"}]

Here are the search results for **Swarm Robotics**:

## Overview

Swarm robotics emphasizes a large number of robots, and the application of swarm principles to robots is called swarm robotics while swarm intelligence refers to the more general set of algorithms.

## Key Characteristics

Swarm robotic platforms take inspiration from nature, such as collective problem solving mechanisms seen in honey bee aggregation. Several defining characteristics include:

- Robots are autonomous, can interact with the surroundings, possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities, do not exploit centralized swarm control or global knowledge, and cooperate with each other to accomplish given tasks.
- Miniaturization is a key factor in swarm robotics, as the effect of thousands of small robots can maximize the swarm-intelligent approach.

## Historical Development

The phrase "swarm robotics" made its first appearance in 1991, but research regarding swarm robotics began to grow in early 2000s.(no content)One of the first international projects was the SWARM-BOTS project (2001-2005), which demonstrated self-organized teams of robots that cooperate to solve complex tasks, with robots taking different roles over time.

## Applications

Potential applications include tasks demanding miniaturization and search and rescue missions, where swarms of robots could be sent to places rescue-workers cannot reach safely to explore unknown environments.(no content)Swarm robotics can also be suited to tasks demanding cheap designs, such as mining or agricultural shepherding tasks.

- Miniaturization is a key factor in swarm robotics, as the effect of thousands of small robots can maximize the swarm-intelligent approach.

## Historical Development

The phrase "swarm robotics" made its first appearance in 1991, but research regarding swarm robotics began to grow in early 2000s.(no content)One of the first international projects was the SWARM-BOTS project (2001-2005), which demonstrated self-organized teams of robots that cooperate to solve complex tasks, with robots taking different roles over time.

## Applications

Potential applications include tasks demanding miniaturization and search and rescue missions, where swarms of robots could be sent to places rescue-workers cannot reach safely to explore unknown environments.(no content)Swarm robotics can also be suited to tasks demanding cheap designs, such as mining or agricultural shepherding tasks.

I've completed the web search for "Unmanned aerial vehicle." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV), also known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.(no content)UAVs include both autonomous drones and remotely piloted vehicles (RPVs), and a UAV is capable of controlled, sustained level flight and is powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.

## History

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, when Austrian forces besieging Venice attempted to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the city.(no content)The Spanish engineer Leonardo Torres Quevedo introduced a radio-based control-system called the Telekino at the Paris Academy of Science in 1903, as a way of testing airships without risking human life.

## Commercial Development

In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations, laying out legal groundwork for consumer drone usage inside the United States.(no content)In 2013, DJI released the first model of the Phantom drone, priced at $629, which was considered one of the most influential consumer drone products ever made, with its affordability, accessibility, and user-friendly software quickly capturing the consumer drone market.

## Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications. These include agriculture, energy, construction, mining, search and rescue, inspection of infrastructure, wildlife monitoring, and law enforcement.

I've completed the web search for "Path planning robotics." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview

Path planning in robotics involves computing a continuous path that connects a start configuration and a goal configuration while avoiding collision with known obstacles.

## Key Concepts

Real-Time Path Planning consists of motion planning methods that can adapt to real-time changes in the environment.(no content)Robot navigation means the robot's ability to determine its own position in its frame of reference and then plan a path towards some goal location.

## Main Approaches

Several algorithmic approaches exist for path planning:

- **Sampling-based algorithms**: Sampling-based algorithms avoid the problem of local minima and are currently considered state-of-the-art for motion planning in high-dimensional spaces.

- **Probabilistic Roadmap (PRM)**: The probabilistic roadmap planner is a motion planning algorithm that solves the problem of determining a path between a starting configuration and a goal configuration while avoiding collisions.

- **Artificial Potential Fields**: The evolutionary artificial potential field method uses a mix of artificial repulsive and attractive forces, where attractive forces originate from the target and repulsive forces come from obstacles.

- **Any-angle Path Planning**: Any-angle path planning algorithms search for a Euclidean shortest path between two points on a grid map while allowing turns to have any angle.

## Applications

Motion planning has several robotics applications, such as autonomy, automation, and robot design in CAD software, as well as applications in other fields such as video games and architectural design.

I've completed the web search for "Wireless communication networks." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview

A wireless network is a computer network that uses wireless data connections between network nodes.(no content)Wireless networking allows homes, telecommunications networks, and business installations to avoid the costly process of introducing cables into a building, or as a connection between various equipment locations.

## Types of Wireless Networks

Examples of wireless networks include cell phone networks, wireless local area networks (WLANs), wireless sensor networks, satellite communication networks, and terrestrial microwave networks.

Key categories include:

- **Cellular Networks**: A cellular network or mobile network is a radio network distributed over land areas called cells, each served by at least one fixed-location transceiver, known as a cell site or base station.

- **Wireless LANs**: A wireless LAN (WLAN) is a wireless computer network that links two or more devices using wireless communication to form a local area network (LAN) within a limited area such as a home, school, computer laboratory, campus, or office building.

- **Ad Hoc Networks**: A wireless ad hoc network (WANET) or mobile ad hoc network (MANET) is a decentralized type of wireless network. The network is ad hoc because it does not rely on a pre-existing infrastructure, such as routers or wireless access points.

## Evolution of Mobile Networks

1G transmitted voice as analog radio signals, while 2G transmitted all communications digitally.(no content)4G provided broadband Internet access for mobile devices, supporting IP telephony, high-definition video, and real-time communication.

I've completed the web search for "Wireless communication networks." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview

A wireless network is a computer network that uses wireless data connections between network nodes.(no content)Wireless networking allows homes, telecommunications networks, and business installations to avoid the costly process of introducing cables into a building, or as a connection between various equipment locations.

## Types of Wireless Networks

Examples of wireless networks include cell phone networks, wireless local area networks (WLANs), wireless sensor networks, satellite communication networks, and terrestrial microwave networks.

Key categories include:

- **Cellular Networks**: A cellular network or mobile network is a radio network distributed over land areas called cells, each served by at least one fixed-location transceiver, known as a cell site or base station.

- **Wireless LANs**: A wireless LAN (WLAN) is a wireless computer network that links two or more devices using wireless communication to form a local area network (LAN) within a limited area such as a home, school, computer laboratory, campus, or office building.

- **Ad Hoc Networks**: A wireless ad hoc network (WANET) or mobile ad hoc network (MANET) is a decentralized type of wireless network. The network is ad hoc because it does not rely on a pre-existing infrastructure, such as routers or wireless access points.

## Evolution of Mobile Networks

1G transmitted voice as analog radio signals, while 2G transmitted all communications digitally.(no content)4G provided broadband Internet access for mobile devices, supporting IP telephony, high-definition video, and real-time communication.

Web search results for query: "Localization robot positioning"

Links: [{"title":"Robot navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_navigation"},{"title":"Monte Carlo localization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte_Carlo_localization"},{"title":"Robotic mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_mapping"},{"title":"Simultaneous localization and mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simultaneous_localization_and_mapping"},{"title":"Mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_robot"},{"title":"Gregory Dudek - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gregory_Dudek"},{"title":"Localization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Localization"},{"title":"Indoor positioning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indoor_positioning_system"},{"title":"Autonomous robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot"},{"title":"Positioning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Positioning_system"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about localization and robot positioning:

## Robot Localization and Positioning

Robot localization denotes the robot's ability to establish its own position and orientation within the frame of reference.(no content)Robot navigation means the robot's ability to determine its own position in its frame of reference and then to plan a path towards some goal location.

### Sensors and Methods

Localization or knowledge of its current location is calculated by one or more means, using sensors such motor encoders, vision, Stereopsis, lasers and global positioning systems.

### Key Techniques

Several important approaches are used in robot positioning:

1. **Monte Carlo Localization (MCL)**: Monte Carlo localization is an algorithm for robots to localize using a particle filter that estimates the position and orientation of a robot as it moves and senses the environment.

2. **SLAM**: Simultaneous localization and mapping is the computational problem of constructing or updating a map of an unknown environment while simultaneously keeping track of an agent's location within it.

3. **Vision-based Navigation**: Vision-based navigation uses computer vision algorithms and optical sensors, including laser-based range finder and photometric cameras using CCD arrays, to extract the visual features required to the localization in the surrounding environment.

### Indoor Positioning

For indoor environments, indoor navigation of robots is possible by IMU based indoor positioning devices.(no content)Electric beacons, Near field communication (NFC), WiFi, Visible light communication (VLC) and Li-Fi and Bluetooth are also used for indoor robot positioning.

Links: [{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Multi-agent planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_planning"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Software agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_agent"},{"title":"Multi-agent pathfinding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_pathfinding"},{"title":"Agent-based model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model"},{"title":"Multiagency Coordination Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiagency_Coordination_Systems"},{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Java Agent Development Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Agent_Development_Framework"},{"title":"Incident Command System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incident_Command_System"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about multi-agent systems coordination:

## Definition and Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Coordination Mechanisms

Middleware offers a first-class design abstraction for multi-agent systems, providing means to govern resource access and agent coordination.(no content)When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language, within the constraints of the system's communication protocol, the approach may lead to a common improvement.(no content)Example languages are Knowledge Query Manipulation Language (KQML) or Agent Communication Language (ACL).

## Multi-Agent Planning

In computer science multi-agent planning involves coordinating the resources and activities of multiple agents.(no content)It can involve agents planning for a common goal, an agent coordinating the plans (plan merging) or planning of others, or agents refining their own plans while negotiating over tasks or resources.

## Key Characteristics

Agents in a multi-agent system have autonomy characteristics—agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, and autonomous. Additionally, multi-agent systems can manifest self-organization as well as self-direction and other control paradigms and related complex behaviors even when the individual strategies of all their agents are simple.

## Modern Applications

With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.(no content)Applications include transportation, logistics, graphics, manufacturing, power systems, smartgrids, and the GIS.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about swarm intelligence algorithms:

## Definition and Overview

Swarm intelligence (SI) is the collective behavior of decentralized, self-organized systems, natural or artificial.(no content)The expression was introduced by Gerardo Beni and Jing Wang in 1989, in the context of cellular robotic systems.

## How Swarm Intelligence Works

Swarm intelligence systems consist typically of a population of simple agents or boids interacting locally with one another and with their environment, with inspiration often coming from nature, especially biological systems. The agents follow very simple rules, and although there is no centralized control structure dictating how individual agents should behave, local, and to a certain degree random, interactions between such agents lead to the emergence of "intelligent" global behavior, unknown to the individual agents.

## Key Algorithms

Two of the most prominent swarm intelligence algorithms are:

**Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO):** Particle swarm optimization (PSO) is a global optimization algorithm for dealing with problems in which a best solution can be represented as a point or surface in an n-dimensional space.(no content)It solves a problem through interactions among a population of candidate solutions, dubbed particles, moving the particles around in the search-space according to simple mathematical formulae that adjust each particle's position and velocity. Each particle's movement is influenced by its own best known position so far, and by the best known position in its topological neighborhood.

**Ant Colony Optimization:** Initially proposed by Marco Dorigo in 1992 in his PhD thesis, the first algorithm was aiming to search for an optimal path in a graph, based on the behavior of ants seeking a path between their colony and a source of food.

## Applications

Swarm intelligence algorithms have numerous practical applications. Swarm intelligence (SI) is increasingly applied in Internet of Things (IoT) systems, and by association to Intent-Based Networking (IBN), due to its ability to handle complex, distributed tasks through decentralized, self-organizing algorithms.(no content)Airlines have used ant-based routing in assigning aircraft arrivals to airport gates, with at Southwest Airlines a software program using swarm theory where each pilot acts like an ant searching for the best airport gate.

Human swarming is another emerging application, where groups of human doctors, when connected together by real-time swarming algorithms, could diagnose medical conditions with substantially higher accuracy than individual doctors, with swarms of human radiologists demonstrating a 33% reduction in diagnostic errors as compared to traditional human methods.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about swarm intelligence algorithms:

## Definition and Overview

Swarm intelligence (SI) is the collective behavior of decentralized, self-organized systems, natural or artificial.(no content)The expression was introduced by Gerardo Beni and Jing Wang in 1989, in the context of cellular robotic systems.

## How Swarm Intelligence Works

Swarm intelligence systems consist typically of a population of simple agents or boids interacting locally with one another and with their environment, with inspiration often coming from nature, especially biological systems. The agents follow very simple rules, and although there is no centralized control structure dictating how individual agents should behave, local, and to a certain degree random, interactions between such agents lead to the emergence of "intelligent" global behavior, unknown to the individual agents.

## Key Algorithms

Two of the most prominent swarm intelligence algorithms are:

**Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO):** Particle swarm optimization (PSO) is a global optimization algorithm for dealing with problems in which a best solution can be represented as a point or surface in an n-dimensional space.(no content)It solves a problem through interactions among a population of candidate solutions, dubbed particles, moving the particles around in the search-space according to simple mathematical formulae that adjust each particle's position and velocity. Each particle's movement is influenced by its own best known position so far, and by the best known position in its topological neighborhood.

**Ant Colony Optimization:** Initially proposed by Marco Dorigo in 1992 in his PhD thesis, the first algorithm was aiming to search for an optimal path in a graph, based on the behavior of ants seeking a path between their colony and a source of food.

## Applications

Swarm intelligence algorithms have numerous practical applications. Swarm intelligence (SI) is increasingly applied in Internet of Things (IoT) systems, and by association to Intent-Based Networking (IBN), due to its ability to handle complex, distributed tasks through decentralized, self-organizing algorithms.(no content)Airlines have used ant-based routing in assigning aircraft arrivals to airport gates, with at Southwest Airlines a software program using swarm theory where each pilot acts like an ant searching for the best airport gate.

Human swarming is another emerging application, where groups of human doctors, when connected together by real-time swarming algorithms, could diagnose medical conditions with substantially higher accuracy than individual doctors, with swarms of human radiologists demonstrating a 33% reduction in diagnostic errors as compared to traditional human methods.
